g.text: Starting from the reports, the geometry optimization of GeSe in the
hydrostatic pressure was carried out. The equilibrium structural parameters, including the lattice
constants and the atomic coordinates, were obtained without the pressure e
GeSe under zero pressure are listed in Table
The values denoted with superscript a and b come fromRef. [
The optimized structure data under zero pressure are in good agreement with the values published
]. Taking into account the overestimation of the lattice constants
by the GGA approximation, the results agree fairly well with the experimental values [
phase, the Ge and Se atom sit in the Wycko
fractional coordinates of the Ge and Se atom are well reproduced in the present work. The Ge atom
bonds with the three nearest neighbor Se atoms. The bond of the Ge–Se in the layer plane is denoted
as I, and the bond nearly perpendicular to the layer plane is represented as II. In addition to the
three nearest Ge–Se bonds, the Ge has two next-nearest nonbonding Se neighbors in the layer plane,
indicated by III as illustrated in Figure
a. The blue dashed line represents the nonbonding interlayer
Ge–Ge distance. The calculated three nearest bond lengths of Ge–Se are I
The next-nearest bond length of Ge–Se III is 3.38 Å. The calculated bonding and nonbonding lengths
display satisfactory agreement with the previous experimental and theoretical reports [
on the equilibriumstructure under zero pressure, we gradually increased the hydrostatic pressure to
observe the structural evolution behavior under pressure. The structural parameters of GeSe were
erent pressures. We found that the structure symmetry of GeSe
changes at 34 GPa froma low-symmetry space group
space group has the same crystal axis as the
phase group, which is a non-standard
phase structure is dynamically stable at 37 GPa, as discussed below. The ﬁnding reveals that the
second-order phase transition of GeSe is induced by pressure. The
b, which also shows a layered structure with eight atoms in a unit cell. In the
phase, the coordination number of each Ge atomis ﬁve, compared to three of the low-pressure
phase structures. The lattice parameters of the
3.68 Å. The four neighbor bond lengths of the Ge–Se in the layer plane are I
The bond length of the Ge–Se–II perpendicular to the layer plane is 2.44 Å. On the experimental
The pressure dependence of the lattice parameters, cell volume, bond length, and bond angle may
provide useful information regarding the original phase transition. To investigate further details of the
ects of pressure, the reduced crystal parameters including lattice constants and cell volume as a
function of hydrostatic pressure are plotted, as shown in Figure
